---
title: Easy Remote Editing on Photon OS 4 from Windows 10/VSCode
author: Jon Waite
type: post
date: 2021-04-26T09:37:48+00:00
url: /2021/04/easy-remote-editing-on-photon-os-4-from-windows-10-vscode/
categories:
  - Microsoft
  - Photon OS
  - VMware
tags:
  - Development
  - Photon OS
  - VSCode

---
I'm a huge fan of [VMware Photon OS][1] as a lightweight Linux distribution for running up quick demo and development environments as well as container hosts. In particular I like the small size and multiple distribution options (including VMware OVA, AWS AMI, Azure VHD and Google GCE formats as well as installation ISO and Raspberry Pi image) Earlier this year version 4.0 was released featuring a Real Time (RT) kernel option, security improvements, performance improvements and support for the latest Linux kernels and utilities.

I'm also a fan of [Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VSCode)][2] as my default development environment, the sheer number and variety of extensions available make this an extremely flexible and easy to use.

While users of Linux and Mac tend to be familiar with SSH shells and key-based authentication, this is not always the case for Windows users, but with recent functionality added to Windows 10 build 1809 (and newer), it's now reasonably straightforward to set up a complete development environment for VSCode running in Windows against a remote Linux (Photon OS) deployment target.

This post is designed to show the steps required to get such an environment set up from scratch (partly as a reference for myself, and hopefully to be useful to others).

The goals I had for this configuration were:

  * Automatic and password-less authentication from Windows 10 to a virtual Photon OS appliance
  * Use a standard Photon OS user account named 'photon' (rather than using the 'root' account)
  * The 'photon' user should also be able to use the Linux <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">sudo</code> command to run commands requiring root permissions (again, without specifying a password)
  * Allow VSCode Secure Shell (SSH) remoting from Windows to the Photon OS VM

The starting point for this configuration is a fresh minimal installation of Photon OS 4.0 (GA) from the **photon-minimal-4.0-1526e30ba.iso** media image and choosing the 'minimal' installation option. The Windows 10 installation is also a fresh installation using the October 2020 installation media.

Next I made sure that all (at the time of writing - April 2021) updates were installed in both Windows 10 and on the Photon OS VM (using <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic"># tdnf -y update</code> from a 'root' command prompt). On the Windows machine I then downloaded and installed the latest version of Microsoft Visual Studio Code 

Windows 10 now has a built-in OpenSSH client which provides everything we need to generate SSH keys and then be able to use these to connect to remote systems, from a PowerShell prompt, first use <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="powershell">ssh-keygen -t ecdsa -b 521</code> to generate a key pair and save these in the default locations (<code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">$HOME\.ssh\id_ecdsa</code> for the private key file and <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">$HOME\.ssh\id_ecdsa.pub</code> for the public key), you can optionally provide a passphrase to protect the private key - this process will work either with or without a passphrase set:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," alt="Generate SSH keys on Windows" width="463" height="439" /> 

**Note:** There is an issue in the version of ssh-agent in Windows 10 which effects RSA key pairs - if you try to use RSA key pairs (the default generated by <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">ssh-keygen</code>), you will probably receive an error <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">warning agent returned different signature type ssh-rsa (expected rsa-sha2-512)</code> when attempting to connect to your Photon VM. This can be fixed by manually updating the <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">ssh-agent</code> in use by Windows, but in this configuration I simply use an ECDSA key pair which doesn't suffer from this issue.

Next we need to add the private key to Windows 10's ssh-agent and set this service to automatically start with Windows so that we can use this to automatically authenticate using our key in future. Open an Administrator PowerShell prompt (since we are manipulating System services, we need this) and use <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">Set-Service ssh-agent -StartupType Automatic</code> then <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">Start-Service ssh-agent</code> and finally <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">ssh-add "C:\Users\<your user name>\.ssh\id_ecdsa"</code>. If you provided a passphrase for your private key you will need to enter this to add the key to <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">ssh-agent</code>:

<img decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," /> 

Next, login to the Photon OS VM console as <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">root</code>, and use the <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">ip a</code> command to find the IP address (if not statically assigned during installation):

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-68917 size-full" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-7.png" alt="Determining the Photon OS IP address" width="750" height="256" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-7.png 750w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-7-300x102.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-7-150x51.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-7-250x85.png 250w" sizes="(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px" /> 

As you can see, in this example my IP address is 192.168.25.158. Next we use <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">useradd -m -G sudo photon</code> to create a new 'photon' user account, <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">passwd photon</code> to set a password on this account and then use <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">echo "photon ALL=NOPASSWD: ALL" >> /etc/sudoers</code> to add a line to the <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">/etc/sudoers</code> file to allow this user to run <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">sudo</code> commands without specifying a password:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," alt="Configure photon user" width="555" height="95" /> 

Now we can attempt to connect from our Windows 10 machine to Photon (using the password we just configured at this stage) using <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">ssh photon@<IP Address of Photon VM></code> we'll be prompted to accept the SSH fingerprint for the host if we haven't connected previously:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," alt="Initial connection to Photon from Windows" width="567" height="132" /> 

While we're here we create the <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">.ssh</code> directory for our <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">authorized_keys</code> file to be copied to in the next step using <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">mkdir /home/photon/.ssh</code>:

<img decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," /> 

Exit from the ssh session and use <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">scp .ssh\id_ecdsa.pub photon@<Photon IP Address>:/home/photon/.ssh/authorized_keys</code> to copy the public key (id\_ecdsa.pub) to the authorized\_keys file with the public key of your Windows 10 user. Make sure you copy the .pub (public) key file:

<img decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," /> 

Now reconnect to the Photon VM using ssh, if everything is working successfully you should not be prompted for a password at all. You should also be able to run <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">sudo</code> commands again without being prompted for a password:

<img decoding="async" class="aligncenter" src="data:image/png;base64," /> 

Next we need to run a couple of commands to allow VSCode to interact with the VM, the first <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">sudo tdnf -y install tar</code> provides the <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">tar</code> utility which the VSCode addon for Linux requires (and is not installed in a Photon OS minimal installation), the second <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">sudo sed -i "s/AllowTcpForwarding no/AllowTcpForwarding yes/g" /etc/ssh/sshd_config</code> allows the default Photon OS sshd process to accept TCP forwarding (another requirement for the VSCode remote connection). Finally the <code class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="generic">sudo systemctl restart sshd</code> makes this change take effect:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="810" height="240" class="wp-image-68918 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8.png 810w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8-300x89.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8-800x237.png 800w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8-768x228.png 768w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8-150x44.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-8-250x74.png 250w" sizes="(max-width: 810px) 100vw, 810px" /> 

Now we have everything configured ready for VSCode, in VSCode add the Remote - SSH extension (if not already installed) by selecting the extensions option (boxes on left side of the screen), then typing 'ssh' into the search box and selecting the 'Remote - SSH' option and click 'Install':

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1023" height="768" class="wp-image-68920 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9.png 1023w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9-300x225.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9-800x601.png 800w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9-768x577.png 768w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9-150x113.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-9-200x150.png 200w" sizes="(max-width: 1023px) 100vw, 1023px" /> 

We can now bring up the VSCode command window (Ctrl + Shift + P), type 'ssh' to filter the available options and select 'Remote-SSH: Add New SSH Host&#8230;' to add our Photon VM:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1024" height="342" class="wp-image-68921 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10.png 1024w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10-300x100.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10-800x267.png 800w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10-768x257.png 768w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10-150x50.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-10-250x83.png 250w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /> 

When prompted, we can enter our ssh connection string to connect to our host:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="597" height="80" class="wp-image-68922 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-11.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-11.png 597w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-11-300x40.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-11-150x20.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-11-250x34.png 250w" sizes="(max-width: 597px) 100vw, 597px" /> 

Next we can update the VSCode configuration file in our home directory to remember this host connection:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="603" height="155" class="wp-image-68923 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-12.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-12.png 603w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-12-300x77.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-12-150x39.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-12-250x64.png 250w" sizes="(max-width: 603px) 100vw, 603px" /> 

Finally we can click 'Connect' to establish the remote connection:

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1024" height="768" class="alignnone wp-image-68924 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13.png 1024w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13-300x225.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13-800x600.png 800w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13-768x576.png 768w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13-150x113.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-13-200x150.png 200w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /> 

If everything has worked, we should now get a VSCode window which is connected to our remove VM ready to use (if prompted to select the Operating System of the remote connection, just select Linux from the menu):

<img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1024" height="768" class="wp-image-68925 size-full aligncenter" src="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14.png" srcset="https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14.png 1024w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14-300x225.png 300w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14-800x600.png 800w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14-768x576.png 768w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14-150x113.png 150w, https://kiwicloud.ninja/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Pasted-14-200x150.png 200w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /> 

**Note:** Sometimes I've had to attempt connecting 2 or 3 times before successful (I'm assuming due to the time taken for the Photon VM to download, unpack and install the VSCode extension), but typically once the connection has succeeded for the first time it will continue to work in future without problems and connect first time from then on.

### Troubleshooting

If you get a hang when attempting to initiate the remote connection from VSCode, this is most likely due to not setting the 'AllowTcpForwarding yes' option in /etc/ssh/sshd_config (or not restarting the sshd service after making this change) in the Photon VM. The default setting (AllowTcpForwarding no') will not work with current versions of the SSH-remote extension for VSCode.

If you get an error when first attempting to connect via SSH, check that you remembered to install the 'tar' package - this is needed to unpack the VSCode software and is not present in a default/minimal Photon OS installation.

Hopefully this will be useful to others, but I know I'll refer back to it when needing to setup a quick VSCode development environment against a Photon OS VM.

Jon.

 

 [1]: https://vmware.github.io/photon/
 [2]: https://code.visualstudio.com/
